properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An additional 2 to 5 cm is expected tonight for southeastern Alberta. Gusty winds continue to cause poor visibilities in blowing snow in open areas. The heavy snow is expected to taper off this evening as the system pushes into Saskatchewan. So far, areas in extreme southern Alberta have seen snowfall accumulations in the 20-30 cm range. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-29T07:59:14-00:00

properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert - Winter Storm Alert Updated
properties.Summary:
Description: There is a winter storm in the southern part of Warner County effecting travel on Highway 4 from Milk River to Coutts. Do not travel. I15 is open to Montana. Travel is not recommended. ### Go to https://511.alberta.ca for Road Report information.
Expires: 2019-12-05T09:52:09-07:00

properties.Author: Village of Coutts

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds gusting near 80 km/h combined with fresh snow will give blizzard conditions beginning Friday morning. These conditions are forecast to persist until early Friday evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-29T14:30:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-28T22:31:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3918090573.2019
Area: Ulukhaktok
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Flurries at times heavy are expected. Snow squalls are likely as a cold northerly flow develops over the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Total snowfall: locally up to 20 cm by Saturday morning. Locations: Northern Nova Scotia and eastern and central Prince Edward Island. Remarks: Flurries at times heavy will develop Friday morning and will persist Friday afternoon and Friday night. Snow squalls with locally poor visibility are likely as well. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-29T17:40:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T01:41:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1769310155.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Locations: Gander to Clarenville. Time span: Friday morning until late Friday afternoon. Remarks: Drizzle will transition to a period of heavy, wet snow on Friday morning, before changing back to drizzle or rain showers later in the day or early Friday night. Accumulations will be variable, with the highest amounts occurring inland and over elevated terrain. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-29T18:15:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T02:16:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1029108558.2019
Area: Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall, followed by significant rainfall, is expected. Total snowfall: 2 to 4 cm, except 10 cm inland and over higher terrain. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm. Locations: Avalon and Burin Peninsulas. Time span: early Friday morning until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Drizzle will transition to wet snow early in the morning on Friday. The snow may be heavy at times, especially over higher terrain, but will then change to rain, at times heavy, later Friday morning. The rain is expected to ease to drizzle or showers Friday afternoon, but periods of rain will likely redevelop Friday night. Wet weather will then continue into Saturday. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-29T18:16:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T02:17:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1954346316.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for significant snowfall and strong winds Friday night through Sunday morning. Locations: along the coast from L'Anse-au-Clair to Hopedale and inland to Upper Lake Melville. Snowfall totals: possibly 15 to 30 cm. Time span: beginning Friday night and ending overnight Saturday night or Sunday. Remarks: Periods of rain, drizzle and snow are expected to continue along the Labrador coast tonight and Friday. On Friday night, the precipitation will intensify. Generally snow is expected inland while coastal areas of southeastern Labrador may see some mixing with rain. Heaviest accumulations are expected north of the Straits area. A snowfall warning has been issued for the Postville-Makkovik area. Peak wind gusts: Possibly 90 to 120 km/h. Time span: Saturday morning to Sunday morning. Remarks: Winds will strengthen out of the northeast on Friday night and potentially reach warning criteria by early Saturday. Strong wind gusts will continue and gradually shift to northwesterly by Saturday night. Coastal areas will have the greatest chance of seeing the strongest wind gusts. Specific locations for strongest gusts will be provided in subsequent forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-29T18:23:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T02:24:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3369048769.2019
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintery mix of precipitation is expected for southeastern Saskatchewan tonight, Friday, and most of Saturday. Another Colorado low will cross the northern plains bringing periods of light snow and freezing drizzle to southeastern Saskatchewan beginning tonight. There will be the potential for prolonged periods of freezing drizzle leading to icy conditions on sidewalks and roadways, though exact timing and duration remain uncertain at this time. This mix of precipitation will continue through late Saturday before moving out of the area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-29T16:46:53-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant high elevation snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm over the Long Range Mountains. Lesser amounts elsewhere. Locations: western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: Friday afternoon until Sunday morning. Remarks: A prolonged period of high-elevation snowfall is expected beginning Friday afternoon and continuing into the weekend. While precipitation will fall as a mixture of snow and rain over the lower elevations near the coast, snow will be dominant over mountainous areas. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions, especially over higher terrain. Anyone planning to use backcountry trails should be prepared for large amounts of snowfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-29T18:16:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T02:17:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3714338023.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintery mix of precipitation is expected for southern Manitoba beginning early Friday and lasting into Sunday. Another Colorado low will cross the northern plains starting early Friday bringing periods of snow and freezing drizzle to southern Manitoba. The mix of precipitation will begin in the southwest spreading eastward throughout the morning. There will be the potential for prolonged periods of freezing drizzle leading to icy conditions on sidewalks and roadways, though exact timing and duration remain uncertain at this time. This mix of precipitation will continue through late Saturday in most areas. Precipitation will then shift over to mainly snow by late Saturday as the system tracks across the Dakotas. Current indications have the heaviest snow and strongest winds in the United States. However, areas along the international border as well as the Manitoba escarpment may see snowfall totals exceed 10 cm by Sunday morning. Reduced visibilities in snow and blowing snow are also possible. The system will depart the area entirely by midday Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-29T16:49:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T00:50:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1092772684.2019
Area: Lake Winnipeg - south basin, Lake Manitoba

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of precipitation are expected. Total snowfall: near 10 cm inland and over over higher terrain. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm along the coast. Locations: Burgeo area to the Connaigre Peninsula. Time span: Friday morning until Saturday evening. Remarks: A mixture of precipitation will develop Friday morning, with mainly rain along the coast and snow inland and over higher elevations. Precipitation will transition to rain over all areas Friday morning and continue into Saturday while gradually tapering off. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A Pacific warm front will move into northern Yukon on Friday bringing snow to the Dempster and strong winds near the Richardson Mountains. East winds of 70 km/h gusting to 90 will develop in the late morning giving poor visibility in blowing snow. Winds are forecast to diminish Friday night as the front moves out of the region. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-29T20:01:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T04:02:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1307081056.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected Friday, and again Saturday. First Snowfall: 10 to 15 cm, with higher amounts possible, from midday Friday until Friday evening. Second Snowfall: 5 to 10 cm from Saturday afternoon to overnight Saturday night. Locations: Grand Falls-Windsor to White Bay. Remarks: Drizzle will transition to a period of heavy, wet snow around midday or early in the afternoon on Friday, before changing back to rain showers or drizzle Friday night. Accumulations will be variable, with the highest amounts occurring inland and over elevated terrain. A second period of potentially significant snowfall will begin again Saturday afternoon as temperatures fall in the wake of the storm. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-29T18:17:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T02:18:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0444142439.2019
Area: Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow is expected. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm inland, with locally higher amounts possible. Total Rainfall: 15 to 30 mm along the coast. Locations: northeast coast of Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning until Friday afternoon. Remarks: Drizzle will transition to a mixture of snow and rain Friday morning before turning back to showers or drizzle later in the day or early Friday night. Snowfall accumulations will be variable, with the highest accumulations likely occurring inland and over elevated terrain. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Conditions will be favourable for the development of snow squalls from Friday morning to Saturday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-29T12:33:24-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 30 to 40 cm is expected. Locations: Postville to Makkovik. Time span: continuing until Sunday. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will continue tonight through until Sunday. Strong winds will cause blowing snow over exposed areas. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Heavy snow Friday and Saturday at Pangnirtung. A low pressure system developing in the western Arctic will move into Foxe Basin Friday. At Pangnirtung, light snow will begin Friday morning and gradually intensify through the day. The bulk of the accumulating snow is expected Friday night and Saturday. The snow will taper off early Sunday morning as system moves off to the east. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
